column4: is there any way to install 8.04 using the existing disk partitions?  I need to retain sda7, but the install wants to start over from the full-disk, wiping out the parition table :(
I am desperately trying to regress to hardy, the last known stable and working ubuntu for the inspiron 1521
rwolf, but it wont give me that option, it only wants to create a single disk whole partition
I thought normally it would detect the existing paritions and offer those wanting mount points, but I don't get that
I am using the alt cd, maybe that's why?
I'm pretty sure that should work (I installed into an existing lvm volume using the alt install cd myself)
what kind of partition table is this?
this sounds like something's going wrong and the kernel's not reading the partition table successfully
iirc you can alt+f2 or something over to a shell, can you check dmesg to see if the partition table is actually recognized?
dmesg|grep sda, is there a line like "sda: sda1 sda2" in there?
ok, so the kernel sees things and the partitioner is doing something odd then?
what kind of filesystem is on the partition you want to install into?
no, I don't mean the type in the partition table, I mean the type actually on the partition. ext4 perhaps?
I don't think I have enough experience with the installer to debug this tbh.
no, 8.04 can't handle ext4. If you're downgrading from 9.04 I wonder if the 8.04 installer is balking on any ext4 partitions it can't handle that 9.04 could.
oh, if there's any lvm involved you might need the alt install cd.
